channel.title: About New Hampshire Mortgage Lenders on NH Mortgage Lenders
channel.description: Recent content in About New Hampshire Mortgage Lenders on NH Mortgage Lenders

item.title: Best New Hampshire Credit Unions for Mortgages: Service CU vs Granite State vs St. Mary's
item.description:
New Hampshire credit unions consistently offer mortgage rates 0.125%–0.25% below retail banks due to non-profit structure and member-focused pricing. The three largest NH mortgage credit unions are Service Credit Union, Granite State Credit Union, and St. Mary’s Bank.

Why NH Credit Unions Have Better Rates

Credit unions are non-profit member cooperatives:

  • No shareholder profit requirements = tighter margins on loans
  • Member surplus returned via better rates and lower fees
  • Lower overhead than retail banks (fewer branches, lean staffing)
  • Community-focused vs profit-maximizing

Typical NH credit union rate advantage: 0.125%–0.25% below Bank of America, TD Bank, or Citizens Bank on conventional and FHA loans.

item.title: National vs Local Lenders for New Hampshire Mortgages: Which is Better?
item.description:
New Hampshire borrowers choosing between national lenders (Rocket, Better, Guaranteed Rate) and local lenders (Service CU, TD Bank, St. Mary’s) face trade-offs between technology-driven efficiency and local market expertise.

How National Lenders Work

National direct lenders operate online-first business models:

Rocket Mortgage:

  • Fully digital application and document upload
  • Automated underwriting in 24–48 hours
  • Offshore processing teams (India, Philippines) for cost reduction
  • National scale ($90B+ annual originations)
  • E-closing options in most states

Better.com:

item.title: Portfolio Lenders in New Hampshire: TD Bank, Citizens, St. Mary's & Manual Underwriting
item.description:
New Hampshire portfolio lenders offer manual underwriting and non-agency loan programs for borrowers who don’t fit Fannie Mae/Freddie Mac guidelines—including self-employed, investors with 5+ properties, and credit-challenged borrowers.

What is Portfolio Lending?

Portfolio lenders keep loans on their balance sheet instead of selling to Fannie/Freddie:

Agency lending (most lenders):

  1. Lender originates loan following Fannie/Freddie guidelines
  2. Lender sells loan to Fannie/Freddie within 30–90 days
  3. Lender gets capital back to fund more loans
  4. Borrower’s loan is serviced by Fannie/Freddie servicer

Portfolio lending:
